article:
The 'American Booksellers Association (ABA)' is a non-profit industry
association founded in 1900 that promotes independent bookstores in the United
States and Canada. The ABA and its members support freedom of speech through the
American Booksellers Foundation for Free Expression, literacy, and programs that
encourage reading. Many independent booksellers are concerned about the
potential negative impact on free speech by giant megachains and nationwide web
retailers. The concern is that publishers cater to these retailers and that
control over what books, and hence what ideas, are available will ultimately
rest in the hands of these few companies. {{Citation
  | last = Dugan first = I. Jeanne title = The Baron of Books journal = Business
  | Week date = 1998-06-29 url =
  | http://www.businessweek.com/1998/26/b3584001.htm
}} 

The ABA has been shrinking from a peak in 1991 when there were 5200 members. {{Citation
  | last = Singer first = Penny title = Independent Bookstores Harvest Their
  | Zeal newspaper = New York Times date = 1999-01-17 url = http://query.nytime-
  | s.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A05E2DF1031F934A25752C0A96F958260}} There
  | were 5500 members with 7000 stores in 1995; {{Citation last = Kawaguchi first = Karen title =
  | Feminist Feast And Famine journal = Publishers Weekly date = 2000-07-24 url
  | = http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/print/20000724/37760-pw-feminist-feast-
  | and-famine.html
  }}  3300 members in 1998; 3100 members with
  4000 stores in 2000; 2794 members in 2001; 2191 members in 2002; {{Citation
  | last = Mutter first = John title = BEA Show Daily: ABA Loses Members, Money
  | journal = Publishers Weekly date = 2002-05-05 url =
  | http://www.publishersweekly.com/article/CA216017.html
  }}  and 1702 members in 2005. {{Citation
  | last = Spearie first = Steven title = A novel approach to selling books
  | newspaper = Norwich Bulletin date = 2008-08-14 url = http://www.norwichbulletin.com/news/business/x418531163/A-novel-approach-
  | to-selling-books}}
 In 2010 the number of members increased for the first time in almost two
decades, with 1410 members, up nine from the previous year. Hillel Italie,
[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/05/24/independent-bookstores-
ge_n_587015.html "Independent Bookstores Get A Boost: American Booksellers
Association Membership Up Since Last Year,"] Huffington Post, May 21,
2010.

In recent years, the ABA has released the number of new member bookstores to
counter media reports of bookstore closings, with 97 opening in 2006; {{cite
press release
  | title = A Plethora of New Independent Bookstores Open in 2006 publisher =
  | American Booksllers Association date = 2007-01-08 url =
  | http://www.bookweb.org/about/press/release072.html accessdate = 2008-11-
  | 24}} 115 stores opened in 2007. {{cite press release title = 115
  | New Independent Bookstores Open in 2007 publisher = American Booksllers
  | Association date = 2008-01-14 url =
  | http://www.bookweb.org/about/press/release0801.html accessdate = 2008-11-
  | 24}}


The ABA sponsored the Book Sense marketing program and associated BookSense.com
web site, intended to preserve a connection between consumers and local
independent bookstores. In June 2008, Book Sense was replaced by IndieBound, a
new program and website. {{cite press release
 | title = BookSense.com Becomes ABA E-commerce Solution publisher = American
 | Booksellers Association date = 2008-06-04 url =
 | http://news.bookweb.org/news/6107.html accessdate = 2008-10-02
 }}  After a period of beta testing, a social network-style community
 feature was launched on the website on September 11, 2008. {{cite
 press release
 | title = New IndieBound Community Launches publisher = American Booksellers
 | Association date = 2008-09-11 url = http://news.bookweb.org/news/6280.html
 | accessdate = 2008-10-02
 }}
